body:
I don't quite understand. As you can see in the following screenshot, something like `chalk.bold.green` will create a function which will apply both `bold` and `green` to the string it's passed. This also works for repeated invocations.

Are you seeing something else?

![screen shot 2014-07-08 at 08 09 48](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3891755/3505780/7b810100-0666-11e4-8ab9-9534fa45bb03.png)
@seanmonstar thank you very much! It seems the _styles array is shared across all instances. I'll fix this asap, and apologies for the issue.

Same issue here (I guess). The following produces two red lines:

```
#!/usr/bin/env coffee

chalk = require 'chalk'

blue = chalk.blue
red = chalk.red

console.log blue 'blue'
console.log red 'red'
```

As I fiddle on a patch for this, I can't think of a way of providing the same API with the same performance. Each getter needs to return a new object (a function), and that function needs to have all the getters set. `Object.defineProperty` is brutal in a loop. Here's the options I see:
1. Live with the performance hit of defining getters on each function. It's not bad at all if you cache the style into a variable, such `var style = chalk.blue.bgRed.bold`, since subsequent uses of `style` won't be triggering new `defineProperty`s. I've added a benchmark that shows with the style cached into a variable.
2. Get ~8x performance of option 1, by setting `__proto__` on the function to an object with the properties already defined. `__proto__` is deprecated, in ES6 it will become `Object.setPrototypeOf`, but it can't be remove any time soon if they don't want to blow up the web. The docs for `__proto__` state that it hurts performance, but comparing the benchmark with using `Object.create()` and `chalk.red._('foo')` showed it was actually slightly slower than this `__proto__` hack.
3. Say to hell it with Sean, just call everything off `chalk` (this is still much slower than caching a couple styles).

# 

Here's the benches with option 2 (and an optimization of not doing `[].slice.call(arguments)`:

```
before
                      chalk
       1,286,288 op/s Â» single style
         943,220 op/s Â» several styles
         245,858 op/s Â» nested styles

after
                      chalk
       1,341,294 op/s Â» single style
         254,177 op/s Â» several styles
       1,843,002 op/s Â» cached styles
         298,379 op/s Â» nested styles
```

issue.title: fix caching of styles

repository.name: chalk
repository.description: ðŸ– Terminal string styling done right

issue.body: If you choose to go with option 2 that I listed in #32, this is the PR.

body:
Thank you so much for looking into it this closely! I've had very little time this past day, but fiddling around I came to the same conclusion as you did.

Seeing how this package receives about [50k downloads](https://www.npmjs.org/package/chalk) each day, I definitely want to maintain complete backwards compatability from version `0.4.0`, and not saddle up all those users with issues like you experienced.

I'm going to have a close look at your pull-request to ensure everything stil works as expected, but I think we're going with `option 2`  - fantastic work in figuring out this solution. I could also only think of 'either drop the caching or wrap the function with the state on each get', but the way you implemented it seems like a lot cleverer solution to the latter than I would have taken :wink: 

Regarding the performance hit: this seems completely acceptable to me, as the huge speed increase between `0.4.0` and `0.5.0` still leaves us with a large net gain. The most important thing now is that everything actually works the same as it used to ;-)

I'm fine with option 2 too. Thanks for looking into this @seanmonstar :D

> showed it was actually slightly slower than this **proto** hack.

How much? If it's negligible I would prefer the blessed way.

> How much? If it's negligible I would prefer the blessed way.

Well, the problem is it would require changing the API. To use the prototype, we'd need to use `Object.create()`, which doesn't return a function. With this, I attached a function onto the new object at `_`, so it was `chalk.red._('foo')`. This way is actually faster than the `__proto__` hack:

```
                      chalk
       3,100,288 op/s Â» single style
         333,368 op/s Â» several styles
       1,899,971 op/s Â» cached styles
         439,495 op/s Â» nested styles
```

However, if you try to cache a style, and cache the `_` function, it won't be bound to the object anymore. So, to make sure it's bound, it'd basically require something like `builder._ = applyStyle.bind(builder);`, which slows things back down.

Plus, this breaks the API, which I imagined is a non-starter.

Alright, thanks for the explanation.

:+1: i'm go with this :)
Same here :-) let me have one last look and I'll merge it in

issue.title: Stop using __proto__?

repository.name: chalk
repository.description: ðŸ– Terminal string styling done right

issue.body:
Modifying `__proto__` slows down the performance of the mutated object and subsequent javascript.
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Object/proto

I would love to use a library that combines ansicolor and ansistyles in an easy to use API but the proto penalty seems too high for a "nice to have" feature. For now I'll stick with using the underlying libs.

Are there any plans to remove the use of `__proto__`?

issue.title: compat: chalk doesn't work because of missing __proto__

repository.name: deno
repository.description: A modern runtime for JavaScript and TypeScript.

Release notes
Package name: chalk
  • 0.5.1 - 2014-07-09
    • Critical bugfix #33 where cached style functions would be reset by declaring new styles. Thanks @ seanmonstar!
    • Further speed improvements #32 in the case of applying only a single style. Again all credit goes to @ seanmonstar.
  • 0.5.0 - 2014-07-04
    • Improved performance by a factor of 83x! (thanks to @ jbnicolai)
    • Ability to nest styles of the same type. (thanks to @ jbnicolai)
    • New .hasColor() method for checking if a string contains color escape codes.
    • New dim and hidden styles.
    • Now used by 1200+ modules.
  • 0.4.0 - 2013-12-13

    0.4.0

  • 0.3.0 - 2013-10-19

    0.3.0

  • 0.2.1 - 2013-08-29

    0.2.1

from chalk GitHub release notes
Package name: commander
  • 2.20.3 - 2019-10-11

    Ran "npm unpublish commander@2.20.2". There is no 2.20.2.

    Fixed

    • Support Node.js 0.10 (Revert #1059)
  • 2.20.1 - 2019-09-28

    Fixed

    • Improve tracking of executable subcommands.

    Changed

    • update development dependencies

    Credits:

    • issue identified by Checkmarx Application Security Research Team
  • 2.20.0 - 2019-04-03
